elements.content: In this report, three new luminescent metal–organic frameworks (LMOFs), [Zn­(L1)2]·CH3CN (1), [Zn­(L1)2] (2), and [Zn­(L1)­(L2)0.5]·NMP (3) (HL1 = 6-aminonicotinic acid; H2L2 = terephthalic acid; and NMP = N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone), have been solvothermally synthesized based on d10 metal ion Zn­(II) and free organic ligands (HL1 and H2L2) in different solvent systems, all of which have been fully characterized. Single crystal data reveal that 1 and 2 are two 2D isomeride but with different space groups, which is caused by the different solvent systems during the synthesis procedure. The introduction of the bridging ligand H2L2 in the solvent system of 2 produces 3 with the 3D microporous framework. The gas sorption exploration of 3 shows an interesting stepwise gas sorption behavior and attractive low-pressure selectivity between CO2 and CH4, which may be used as a potential material to separate the CO2 from the natural gas. In addition, the luminescent properties of the free ligands and 1–3 have been investigated carefully, and the luminescent mechanisms have also been verified by the DFT calculation of HOMO, LUMO, and HOMO–LUMO gaps of free ligands and 1–3.

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Currently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been of great interest as a new kind of molecular material and can be used in many fields, such as gas storage/separation, drug delivery, catalysis, nonlinear optics, or sensor materials. So far, a handful of porous MOFs have been widely investigated in gas storage/separation and luminescence by chemists due to their tunable structures, high surface/pore volume, and controllable chemical environment. As is well-known, MOFs can be generated by various synthesis methods, for example, combining the same/different organic ligands with the same/different center metal ions, introducing the different solvent systems, changing the lengths of the organic ligands, or incorporating mixed ligands and so on. Thus, how to synthesize uncommon MOFs with targeted structures and properties remains a great challenge for research workers.

elements.content: Now, the rational selection of ligands and reaction conditions is very important for the assembly of targeted MOFs; numerous rigid O-donor ligands have been extensively used and researched to obtain the desired porous crystalline materials because of their predictable coordination and bridging fashions. In addition, the aromatic rigid N-donor linkers are frequently used as ancillary bridging/chelating ligands to control the final networks and properties of targeted MOFs during the assembly process. The rigid N-donor linkers can often provide interaction sites and increase the pore space in the MOFs, and the pore surface equipped with the interaction sites can help the materials with regard to the selective properties in gas sorption. Thus, it has been documented that the co-regulation of the O,N-donor ligands has been successfully explored in porous MOFs with attractive gas storage/separation in CO2/CH4 separation and luminescent properties as optical materials.

In addition, the aromatic rigid N-donor linkers are frequently used as ancillary bridging/chelating ligands to control the final networks and properties of targeted MOFs during the assembly process. The rigid N-donor linkers can often provide interaction sites and increase the pore space in the MOFs, and the pore surface equipped with the interaction sites can help the materials with regard to the selective properties in gas sorption. Thus, it has been documented that the co-regulation of the O,N-donor ligands has been successfully explored in porous MOFs with attractive gas storage/separation in CO2/CH4 separation and luminescent properties as optical materials.

elements.content: Our group has long been committed to building the uncommon porous MOFs by using the single/mixed ligands and different center metal ions, most of which show fantastic structures and excellent properties in gas adsorption/separation and photoluminescence. Based on the above discussions and our previous work, two rigid and linear-shaped 6-aminonicotinic acid (HL1) and terephthalic acid (H2L2) were chosen as the organic linkers because of their predictable coordination model to bind with the d10 metal ion Zn­(II) in different solvent systems. Fortunately, three new MOFs, [Zn­(L1)2]·CH3CN (1), [Zn­(L1)2] (2), and [Zn­(L1)­(L2)0.5]·NMP (3), have been successfully synthesized. Comparative structural analysis reveals that 1 and 2 are two 2D isomeride but with different space groups, caused by existance of solvent molecules in the network. Furthermore, the introduction of the bridging ligand H2L2 in the solvent system of 2 gives rise to 3 with a 3D microporous framework. The gas sorption exploration of 3 shows an interesting stepwise gas sorption behavior and attractive low-pressure selectivity between CO2 and CH4. Moreover, the luminescent properties of the free ligands and 1–3 have been investigated, and the luminescent mechanisms have also been identified by the DFT calculation of HOMO, LUMO, and HOMO–LUMO gaps of free ligands and 1–3. The experiment results are consistent with the findings of the DFT calculation.

elements.content: All materials and reagents were commercially available and used directly without further purification. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were collected on a PerkinElmer 2400C Elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were obtained with KBr pellets on a Bruker EQUINOX-55 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000–400 cm–1. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained in a nitrogen stream using a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer in the temperature range of 30–700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1. The luminescent spectra of the solid state products were carried out with a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. The sorption isotherms were measured by using Micrometrics ASAP 2020M.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All materials and reagents were commercially available and used directly without further purification. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) measurements were carried out on Bruker D8 ADVANCE X-ray powder diffractometer (Cu Kα, 1.5418 Å) at room temperature. Elemental analyses of C, H, and N were collected on a PerkinElmer 2400C Elemental analyzer. Infrared spectra were obtained with KBr pellets on a Bruker EQUINOX-55 FT-IR spectrometer in the range of 4000-400 cm-1. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) data were obtained in a nitrogen stream using a NETZSCH STA 449C microanalyzer in the temperature range of 30-700 °C with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1. The luminescent spectra of the solid state products were carried out with a Hitachi F-4500 fluorescence spectrophotometer at room temperature. The sorption isotherms were measured by using Micrometrics ASAP 2020M.

elements.content: A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), HL1 (0.2 mmol), CH3CN (6 mL), and H2O (4 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 1 h after which the mixture was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The vessel was heated at 145 °C for 3 days and then the reactor was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h–1. The colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield 57% (based on HL1). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1: C, 44.17; H, 3.44; N, 18.4. Found: C, 44.25; H, 3.58; N, 18.29. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3468 (m), 3328 (s), 3213 (m), 1632 (s), 1371 (s), 1155 (m), 790 (m), 540 (w).

The vessel was heated at 145 °C for 3 days and then the reactor was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h-1. The colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield 57% (based on HL1). elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1–3 were collected on the Bruker SMART APEX II CCD detector equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using a ϕ/ω scan technique at 293(2) K. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXTL program and SHELXL-2014. The adsorption data were modified for absorption by using the program SADABS. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were placed in calculated idealized positions and refined with attached atoms with isotropic thermal parameters. The solvent molecules (NMP) in 3 were disordered and not located, and the SQUEEZE method was applied to remove the contributions of disordered guest molecules. Crystallographic data of 1–3 are displayed in . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 (Supporting Information). CCDC reference numbers are 1534572–1534574 for 1–3.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallographic Data Collection and Refinement

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction data of 1-3 were collected on the Bruker SMART APEX II CCD detector equipped with a graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by using a ϕ/ω scan technique at 293(2) K. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined anisotropically on F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique using the SHELXTL program and SHELXL-2014. The adsorption data were modified for absorption by using the program SADABS. Non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms of organic ligands were placed in calculated idealized positions and refined with attached atoms with isotropic thermal parameters. The solvent molecules (NMP) in 3 were disordered and not located, and the SQUEEZE method was applied to remove the contributions of disordered guest molecules. Crystallographic data of 1-3 are displayed in . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table S1 (Supporting Information). CCDC reference numbers are 1534572-1534574 for 1-3.

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 shows a 2D layered structure and crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn­(II) ion, two deprotonated L1– ligand, and one lattice acetonitrile molecule. As illustrated in , the center Zn­(II) ion is four-coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of two L1– ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from other two different L1–, respectively. The bond lengths {Zn–X = [1.955(4)–2.075(4) Å] (X = N or O)} and angles {X–Zn–X = [100.7(2)°–135.2(2)°] (X = N or O)} are in the normal range. Each Zn­(II) ion is connected by four different L1– ligands and each L1– ligand is linked by two Zn­(II) ions, resulting in a (4,4) network with a rhomboid window (a). The angles of Zn–Zn–Zn are 79.66° and 100.34°, respectively. Then, the weak H-bonds [N1–H1B···O2 = 2.21 Å] (Figure. 2b) contacts between amino and carboxylate groups from different L1– to support the layered nets into a 3D dense packing structure (c). Topologically, the center Zn­(II) ions can be viewed as a 4-connected node; thus the network of 1 can be simplified as a uninodal 4-connected sql net with a point symbol of (44·62) (d).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure of [Zn(L1)2]⋅CH3CN (1)

Single-crystal X-ray analysis reveals that complex 1 shows a 2D layered structure and crystallizes in the monoclinic C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit consists of one Zn(II) ion, two deprotonated L1- ligand, and one lattice acetonitrile molecule. As illustrated in , the center Zn(II) ion is four-coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two carboxylate groups of two L1- ligands, and two nitrogen atoms from other two different L1-, respectively. The bond lengths {Zn-X = [1.955(4)-2.075(4) Å] (X = N or O)} and angles {X-Zn-X = [100.7(2)°-135.2(2)°] (X = N or O)} are in the normal range. Each Zn(II) ion is connected by four different L1- ligands and each L1- ligand is linked by two Zn(II) ions, resulting in a (4,4) network with a rhomboid window (a). The angles of Zn-Zn-Zn are 79.66° and 100.34°, respectively. Then, the weak H-bonds [N1-H1B⋅⋅⋅O2 = 2.21 Å] (Figure. 2b) contacts between amino and carboxylate groups from different L1- to support the layered nets into a 3D dense packing structure (c). Topologically, the center Zn(II) ions can be viewed as a 4-connected node; thus the network of 1 can be simplified as a uninodal 4-connected  sql  net with a point symbol of (44⋅62) (d).

elements.content: In comparison with 1, the only difference is that the solvent CH3CN was replaced by NMP during the synthesis process to yield 2. Interestingly, single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that 1 and 2 are isomeride. In contrast to 1, 2 crystallizes in the chiral tetragonal P41212 space group, which leads to the 2D layered structure with 1D left and right-handed helices. The asymmetric fundamental unit consists of one independent Zn­(II) ion and two deprotonated L1– ligand. Similarly to 1, the center Zn­(II) ion adopts a distorted tetrahedral gemometry defined by two nitrogen and two oxygen atoms from four different L1– ligands (). The bond lengths {Zn–X = [1.962(3)–2.070(3) Å] (X = N or O)} and angles {X–Zn–X = [99.51(17)°–136.3(4)°] (X = N or O)} are in the normal range.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Zn(L1)2] (2)

In comparison with 1, the only difference is that the solvent CH3CN was replaced by NMP during the synthesis process to yield 2. Interestingly, single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis shows that 1 and 2 are isomeride. In contrast to 1, 2 crystallizes in the chiral tetragonal P41212 space group, which leads to the 2D layered structure with 1D left and right-handed helices. The asymmetric fundamental unit consists of one independent Zn(II) ion and two deprotonated L1- ligand. Similarly to 1, the center Zn(II) ion adopts a distorted tetrahedral gemometry defined by two nitrogen and two oxygen atoms from four different L1- ligands (). The bond lengths {Zn-X = [1.962(3)-2.070(3) Å] (X = N or O)} and angles {X-Zn-X = [99.51(17)°-136.3(4)°] (X = N or O)} are in the normal range.

elements.content: In 2, the oxygen and nitrogen atoms of the carboxylate group of the L1– adopts monodentate coordination with the Zn­(II) ions, resulting into an undulating 2D sql (4,4) net with a square window (). Herein, the angles of Zn–Zn–Zn (90°) make the two types of chiral helices with the screw pitch of 11.14 Å exist (a and S1) in different directions in the layer. These single-handed helical chains are further interconnected into a 2D chiral layer by sharing the center Zn­(II) ions. The adjacent layers are further connected via H-bonds [N2–H2B···O2 = 2.275 Å] (Figure S2) in a 3D supramolecular network with ···ABCD··· model (b).

elements.content: In comparison with 1 and 2, the introduction of the bridging ligand H2L2 helps to extend the 2D layered networks into a 3D porous framework during the synthesis procedure of 3. Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group with a 3D non-interpenetrated porous MOF based on the dinuclear paddle-wheel shaped [Zn2(CO2)4N2] SBUs. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn­(II) cation, one deprotonated L1–, half of the fully deprotonated L22– ligand, and one guest NMP molecule. As illustrated in , the center Zn­(II) cation adopts a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry five-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups of two different L1– ligands, two different L22– ligands, and one nitrogen atom from one L1– ligand.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of [Zn(L1)(L2)0.5]⋅NMP (3)

In comparison with 1 and 2, the introduction of the bridging ligand H2L2 helps to extend the 2D layered networks into a 3D porous framework during the synthesis procedure of 3. Complex 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group with a 3D non-interpenetrated porous MOF based on the dinuclear paddle-wheel shaped [Zn2(CO2)4N2] SBUs. The asymmetric unit contains one Zn(II) cation, one deprotonated L1-, half of the fully deprotonated L22- ligand, and one guest NMP molecule. As illustrated in , the center Zn(II) cation adopts a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry five-coordinated by four oxygen atoms from four carboxylate groups of two different L1- ligands, two different L22- ligands, and one nitrogen atom from one L1- ligand.

elements.content: The four carboxylate groups adopt the same μ2-η1:η1 mode with two Zn­(II) ions, which produce the dinuclear paddle-wheel shaped [Zn2(CO2)4N2] SBUs (a). The L1– ligands connect these SBUs into a 2D layered structure (b); further, the linear L22– acts as rod pillars to support these adjacent 2D layers into a 3D open microporous network with an open window (10.92 × 6.62 Å2) (c and S3). Topologically, the whole framework of 3 can be simplified as a uninodal 6-connected pcu network with the point symbol (412·63) (d).

elements.content: Structural analyses show that the solvent system and auxiliary ligand play the decisive role for the final structures of MOFs. In 1 and 2, the only differences is the solvent system were induced during the synthesis procedure (CH3CN for 1, NMP for 2), meaning that 1 and 2 are isomeride but with different space groups. Single crystal analysis show that there exist solvent molecules (CH3CN) between the adjacent 2D layers of 1, and further, the van der Waals force between CH3CN and the layer makes the shape of the quadrilateral grid, which is different from that of 2 (Figure S5) and results in transformation in the space group from monoclinic C2/c to chiral tetragonal P41212. By comparison of the structures of 2 and 3, it is found that 3 possesses a higher-dimensional (3D) network. The major reason is that when the bridging ligand H2L2 is added in the reaction system of 3, the linear bridging H2L2 ligands can act as the pillars to support the adjacent 2D layers to form a 3D microporous framework.
elements.clean_text:
Role of the Solvents and Auxiliary Ligand in Regulating the Final Structure of 1-3 

Structural analyses show that the solvent system and auxiliary ligand play the decisive role for the final structures of MOFs. In 1 and 2, the only differences is the solvent system were induced during the synthesis procedure (CH3CN for 1, NMP for 2), meaning that 1 and 2 are isomeride but with different space groups. Single crystal analysis show that there exist solvent molecules (CH3CN) between the adjacent 2D layers of 1, and further, the van der Waals force between CH3CN and the layer makes the shape of the quadrilateral grid, which is different from that of 2 (Figure S5) and results in transformation in the space group from monoclinic C2/c to chiral tetragonal P41212. By comparison of the structures of 2 and 3, it is found that 3 possesses a higher-dimensional (3D) network. The major reason is that when the bridging ligand H2L2 is added in the reaction system of 3, the linear bridging H2L2 ligands can act as the pillars to support the adjacent 2D layers to form a 3D microporous framework.

elements.content: The experimental PXRD patterns of the obtained crystalline samples match well with those simulated from the single crystal data of MOFs, confirming the phase purity to support further study (Figure S6). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1–3 were also carried out to investigate the thermal stability (Figure S7). The TGA curves of 1–3 show that there exist two, one- and two-step, weight losses for 1–3, respectively, which are consistent with the structures of 1–3. Structure analysis of 1 and 3 shows that there are solvent molecules in the framework, so the TGA curves of 1 and 3 reveal that the first weight loss is ascribed to the loss of the lattice solvent molecule, and then the ligands decompose and the entire frameworks collapse. As for 2, there are no lattice molecules in the network, and thus its TGA curve shows one-step weight loss of the ligand; after that the structure begins to collapse beyond the stable temperature.
elements.clean_text:
PXRD and TGA

The experimental PXRD patterns of the obtained crystalline samples match well with those simulated from the single crystal data of MOFs, confirming the phase purity to support further study (Figure S6). Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) of 1-3 were also carried out to investigate the thermal stability (Figure S7). The TGA curves of 1-3 show that there exist two, one- and two-step, weight losses for 1-3, respectively, which are consistent with the structures of 1-3. Structure analysis of 1 and 3 shows that there are solvent molecules in the framework, so the TGA curves of 1 and 3 reveal that the first weight loss is ascribed to the loss of the lattice solvent molecule, and then the ligands decompose and the entire frameworks collapse. As for 2, there are no lattice molecules in the network, and thus its TGA curve shows one-step weight loss of the ligand; after that the structure begins to collapse beyond the stable temperature.

elements.content: To remove the guest solvent molecules and obtain the guest-free phase of 3a, the synthesized sample 3 was soaked in CH2Cl2 for 72 h (6 × 12 h) followed by heating at 120 °C under vacuum for 4 h, and then the guest-free phase 3a was obtained, which is identified by the TGA curves of 3 and 3a (Figure S7b) and FT-IR (Figure S8c). The FT-IR of 3a shows the lack of characteristic CO vibration of NMP, revealing that the disordered solvent has been removed from the channels. After the hypothetical removal of the noncoordinated and disordered solvent molecules, the potential solvent area volume of 3a-[Zn­(L1)­(L2)0.5] is determined to be ∼44.4% (717 Å3) out of the total volume of the unit cell (1613.4 Å3) by the PLATON program. The structural integrity of 3a has been confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S6). The desolvated sample-3a was used for the further gas sorption study.
elements.clean_text: To remove the guest solvent molecules and obtain the guest-free phase of 3a, the synthesized sample 3 was soaked in CH2Cl2 for 72 h (6 × 12 h) followed by heating at 120 °C under vacuum for 4 h, and then the guest-free phase 3a was obtained, which is identified by the TGA curves of 3 and 3a (Figure S7b) and FT-IR (Figure S8c). The FT-IR of 3a shows the lack of characteristic CO vibration of NMP, revealing that the disordered solvent has been removed from the channels. After the hypothetical removal of the noncoordinated and disordered solvent molecules, the potential solvent area volume of 3a-[Zn(L1)(L2)0.5] is determined to be ~44.4% (717 Å3) out of the total volume of the unit cell (1613.4 Å3) by the PLATON program. The structural integrity of 3a has been confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (Figure S6). The desolvated sample-3a was used for the further gas sorption study.

elements.content: After completely removing the guest solvent molecule from the framework of 3, the permanent porosity of 3a is confirmed by the N2 and CO2 sorption isotherm at 77 and 195 K by activating at 120 °C under vacuum for 2 h (). Interestingly, the isotherm exhibits unusual reversible stepwise isotherms for N2 (77 K) and CO2 (195 K). It can be seen that 3a shows a low uptake in the low pressure region (P/P 0 = 0.01 for N2; P = 15 mmHg for CO2), and then displays a sudden increase in gas uptake at higher pressure and slowly reaches the final uptake amounts of 100 cm3 g–1 for N2 and 150 cm3 g–1 for CO2. From the structure analysis and gas sorption behavior, this uncommon phenomenon may be caused by rotation of the benzene ring at low pressure, causing almost no gas uptake. The window of the porous network may be opened by the increasing pressure, causing the sudden gas sorption of N2 and CO2 to show interesting stepwise isotherms. The BET surface area and Langmuir surface area of 3a are obtained 153.5 m2 g–1 and 214.6 m2 g–1 based on N2 adsorption isotherm, respectively. The experimental pore size distribution (PSD) curve reveals that there exists only one kind of pore based on the NLDFT model, which matches well with the crystal structure (Figures S9 and S3). The H2 and CH4 sorption measurements at 77 and 195 K have also been investigated to explore the storage capacity of the fuel gases (Figure S10).
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Properties

After completely removing the guest solvent molecule from the framework of 3, the permanent porosity of 3a is confirmed by the N2 and CO2 sorption isotherm at 77 and 195 K by activating at 120 °C under vacuum for 2 h (). Interestingly, the isotherm exhibits unusual reversible stepwise isotherms for N2 (77 K) and CO2 (195 K). It can be seen that 3a shows a low uptake in the low pressure region (P/P 0 = 0.01 for N2; P = 15 mmHg for CO2), and then displays a sudden increase in gas uptake at higher pressure and slowly reaches the final uptake amounts of 100 cm3 g-1 for N2 and 150 cm3 g-1 for CO2. From the structure analysis and gas sorption behavior, this uncommon phenomenon may be caused by rotation of the benzene ring at low pressure, causing almost no gas uptake. The window of the porous network may be opened by the increasing pressure, causing the sudden gas sorption of N2 and CO2 to show interesting stepwise isotherms. The BET surface area and Langmuir surface area of 3a are obtained 153.5 m2 g-1 and 214.6 m2 g-1 based on N2 adsorption isotherm, respectively. The experimental pore size distribution (PSD) curve reveals that there exists only one kind of pore based on the NLDFT model, which matches well with the crystal structure (Figures S9 and S3). The H2 and CH4 sorption measurements at 77 and 195 K have also been investigated to explore the storage capacity of the fuel gases (Figure S10).

elements.content: The sorption behaviors of CO2 and CH4 were also experimented at 273 and 298 K. As shown in a, the uptakes of CO2 and CH4 were 13.5/8 and 5/3 cm3 g–1, respectively. The gas sorption isotherms of 3a show the hysteresis behavior, which may be caused by the flexible host framework of 3. The uptake of CH4 is much lower than that of CO2, which indicated significant gas adsorption selectivities for CO2 over CH4 at 273 and 298 K. The ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) (Figure S11) used to predict the adsorption selectivities for a CO2/CH4 binary mixture of 3a. As shown in b and c, the selectivities for CO2/CH4 mixtures with general feed compositions of landfill gas (CO2/CH4 = 50:50) predicted are 2.9 at 273 K and 3 at 298 K at 1 atm, which are comparable to those of known MOFs. The significant sorption selectivity for CO2 over CH4 of 3a is mainly attributed to the differences of the electrostatic behavior between the porous surface and adsorbates (the −NH2 in the pore surface may enhance the electrostatic behavior with the CO2 molecules). In addition, the smaller kinetic diameter, CO2 (3.30 Å) and CH4 (3.80 Å), which makes the CO2 molecules match well with the narrow pore size of 3a (10.92 × 6.62 Å2), the resulting CO2 molecules easily diffuse into the pores. Moreover, the adsorption affinity of 3a for CO2 can be evaluated by the adsorption isosteric heat (Q st) calculated by the virial equation from the adsorption isotherms of CO2 at 273 and 298 K (Figure S12). As shown in , the adsorption enthalpy (Q st) is 23.1 kJ mol–1, which is relatively lower than those of reported MOFs, such as MIL-101 (45 kJ mol–1) and Zn-MOF-74 (30 kJ mol–1), and relatively higher than that of PCN-16 (22.5 kJ mol–1) and so on. The Q st decreases with increasing gas adsorption, and still reaches 15.8 kJ mol–1, showing the strong interactions between the framework and the CO2. The adsorption enthalpies of 3a reveal the low-energy consumption for adsorbent regeneration, implying an ideal property for separation in CO2 and CH4.

elements.content: The solid state luminescent properties of the free organic ligands (HL1 and H2L2) and 1–3 were evaluated at room temperature. As shown in , the maximum emission peaks of HL1 and H2L2 were observed at 390 nm (λex = 300 nm) and 391 nm (λex = 335 nm), which can be assigned to the intraligand π–π* or n−π* transition of HL1 and H2L2. Compared with the free organic ligands, the maximum emissions of 1–3 were observed at 483 nm (λex = 380 nm), 498 nm (λex = 425 nm), and 499 nm (λex = 410 nm), revealing the obvious 100 nm red-shift. The red-shift may be the result of the coordination interactions, and the crystal packing interactions in the solid products can enable the rigidity of the aromatic backbones and reduce the loss of energy by radiationless decay of the intraligand. And then, the structural arrangement of 1–3 may decrease the intraligand HOMO–LUMO energy gap.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent Properties

The solid state luminescent properties of the free organic ligands (HL1 and H2L2) and 1-3 were evaluated at room temperature. As shown in , the maximum emission peaks of HL1 and H2L2 were observed at 390 nm (λex = 300 nm) and 391 nm (λex = 335 nm), which can be assigned to the intraligand π-π* or n-π* transition of HL1 and H2L2. Compared with the free organic ligands, the maximum emissions of 1-3 were observed at 483 nm (λex = 380 nm), 498 nm (λex = 425 nm), and 499 nm (λex = 410 nm), revealing the obvious 100 nm red-shift. The red-shift may be the result of the coordination interactions, and the crystal packing interactions in the solid products can enable the rigidity of the aromatic backbones and reduce the loss of energy by radiationless decay of the intraligand. And then, the structural arrangement of 1-3 may decrease the intraligand HOMO-LUMO energy gap.

elements.content: Solid-state luminescence emission spectra of H1L1, H2L2, 1, 2, and 3.
elements.clean_text: 10  Solid-state luminescence emission spectra of H1L1, H2L2, 1, 2, and 3.

elements.content: In order to give a reasonable explanation of the luminescence properties, theoretically calculated highest occupied molecular orbitals (HOMOs) and the lowest unoccupied molecular orbitals (LUMOs) of HL1, H2L2, and 1–3 were used to investigate its optical mechanism. As shown in Figure S13 and , the fluorescent red-shift of 1–3 may be caused by the coordination interactions and crystal packing rigidity of the ligand and reduce the loss of energy by radiationless decay of the intraligand emission excited state. Further, the change of structural arrangement of 1–3 may decrease the intraligand HOMO–LUMO energy gap, which may be the main factor leading to the fluorescence red-shift. The results show that 1–3 may be excellent candidates as potential inorganic–organic luminescent materials.

The results show that 1-3 may be excellent candidates as potential inorganic-organic luminescent materials.

Three new Zn­(II)-based luminescent MOFs have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. Complexes 1 and 2 are two 2D isomeride but with different space groups, which are caused by the different solvent systems. Complex 3 displays a higher-dimensional 3D microporous framework when adding the bridging ligand H2L2 in the solvent system of 2. The gas sorption behavior of 3 shows an attractive low-pressure selectivity between CO2 and CH4, which may be used as a potential material to separate CO2 from the natural gas. In addition, the luminescent properties of the free ligands and 1–3 have been investigated, and the luminescent mechanisms have also been explored by the DFT calculation of HOMO, LUMO, and HOMO–LUMO gaps of free ligands and 1–3.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Three new Zn(II)-based luminescent MOFs have been successfully synthesized and structurally characterized. Complexes 1 and 2 are two 2D isomeride but with different space groups, which are caused by the different solvent systems. Complex 3 displays a higher-dimensional 3D microporous framework when adding the bridging ligand H2L2 in the solvent system of 2. The gas sorption behavior of 3 shows an attractive low-pressure selectivity between CO2 and CH4, which may be used as a potential material to separate CO2 from the natural gas. In addition, the luminescent properties of the free ligands and 1-3 have been investigated, and the luminescent mechanisms have also been explored by the DFT calculation of HOMO, LUMO, and HOMO-LUMO gaps of free ligands and 1-3.

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), HL1 (0.2 mmol), CH3CN (6 mL), and H2O (4 mL) was stirred at room temperature for 1 h after which the mixture was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel. The vessel was heated at 145 °C for 3 days and then the reactor was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h–1. The colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield 57% (based on HL1). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 1: C, 44.17; H, 3.44; N, 18.4. Found: C, 44.25; H, 3.58; N, 18.29. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3468 (m), 3328 (s), 3213 (m), 1632 (s), 1371 (s), 1155 (m), 790 (m), 540 (w).

Synthesis of Zn­(L1)<sub>2</sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), HL1 (0.2 mmol), NMP (6 mL), and H2O (4.0 mL) were sealed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel and then heated at 145 °C for 72 h. After a gradual cooling procedure to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h–1, colorless block crystals were obtained. Yield 48% (based on HL1). Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 2: C, 42.44; H, 2.97; N, 16.50; Found: C, 42.32; H, 3.15; N, 16.35. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3484 (m), 3337 (s), 3228 (m), 1625 (s), 1374 (s), 1164 (m), 1032 (m), 782 (m), 676 (w), 545­(m), 414 (w).

Synthesis of [Zn­(L1)­(L2)<sub>0.5</sub>]·NMP (<bold>3</bold>)

A mixture of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (0.1 mmol), HL1 (0.1 mmol), H2L2 (0.1 mmol), NMP (6 mL), and H2O (4.0 mL) was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated to 145 °C for 72 h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h–1. The colorless block crystals of 3 were isolated in a yield of 45% based on HL1. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 3: C, 48.22; H, 1.62; N, 11.25. Found: C, 48.35; H, 1.75; N, 11.32. FT-IR (KBr, cm–1): 3403 (m), 3337 (m), 3219 (m), 2862 (m), 1651 (s), 1388 (s), 993 (w), 782 (m), 542 (w), 440 (w).

Synthesis of [Zn(L1)(L2)0.5]⋅NMP (3)

A mixture of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (0.1 mmol), HL1 (0.1 mmol), H2L2 (0.1 mmol), NMP (6 mL), and H2O (4.0 mL) was placed in a 15 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel, heated to 145 °C for 72 h, and then cooled to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C h-1. The colorless block crystals of 3 were isolated in a yield of 45% based on HL1. Elemental analysis calcd (%) for 3: C, 48.22; H, 1.62; N, 11.25. Found: C, 48.35; H, 1.75; N, 11.32. FT-IR (KBr, cm-1): 3403 (m), 3337 (m), 3219 (m), 2862 (m), 1651 (s), 1388 (s), 993 (w), 782 (m), 542 (w), 440 (w).

cln_elements.content:
The four carboxylate groups adopt the same μ2-η1:η1 mode with two Zn­(II) ions, which produce the dinuclear paddle-wheel shaped [Zn2(CO2)4N2] SBUs (a). The L1– ligands connect these SBUs into a 2D layered structure (b); further, the linear L22– acts as rod pillars to support these adjacent 2D layers into a 3D open microporous network with an open window (10.92 × 6.62 Å2) (c and S3). Topologically, the whole framework of 3 can be simplified as a uninodal 6-connected pcu network with the point symbol (412·63) (d).

Sorption Properties

After completely removing the guest solvent molecule from the framework of 3, the permanent porosity of 3a is confirmed by the N2 and CO2 sorption isotherm at 77 and 195 K by activating at 120 °C under vacuum for 2 h (). Interestingly, the isotherm exhibits unusual reversible stepwise isotherms for N2 (77 K) and CO2 (195 K). It can be seen that 3a shows a low uptake in the low pressure region (P/P 0 = 0.01 for N2; P = 15 mmHg for CO2), and then displays a sudden increase in gas uptake at higher pressure and slowly reaches the final uptake amounts of 100 cm3 g–1 for N2 and 150 cm3 g–1 for CO2. From the structure analysis and gas sorption behavior, this uncommon phenomenon may be caused by rotation of the benzene ring at low pressure, causing almost no gas uptake. The window of the porous network may be opened by the increasing pressure, causing the sudden gas sorption of N2 and CO2 to show interesting stepwise isotherms. The BET surface area and Langmuir surface area of 3a are obtained 153.5 m2 g–1 and 214.6 m2 g–1 based on N2 adsorption isotherm, respectively. The experimental pore size distribution (PSD) curve reveals that there exists only one kind of pore based on the NLDFT model, which matches well with the crystal structure (Figures S9 and S3). The H2 and CH4 sorption measurements at 77 and 195 K have also been investigated to explore the storage capacity of the fuel gases (Figure S10).

The sorption behaviors of CO2 and CH4 were also experimented at 273 and 298 K. As shown in a, the uptakes of CO2 and CH4 were 13.5/8 and 5/3 cm3 g–1, respectively. The gas sorption isotherms of 3a show the hysteresis behavior, which may be caused by the flexible host framework of 3. The uptake of CH4 is much lower than that of CO2, which indicated significant gas adsorption selectivities for CO2 over CH4 at 273 and 298 K. The ideal adsorbed solution theory (IAST) (Figure S11) used to predict the adsorption selectivities for a CO2/CH4 binary mixture of 3a. As shown in b and c, the selectivities for CO2/CH4 mixtures with general feed compositions of landfill gas (CO2/CH4 = 50:50) predicted are 2.9 at 273 K and 3 at 298 K at 1 atm, which are comparable to those of known MOFs. The significant sorption selectivity for CO2 over CH4 of 3a is mainly attributed to the differences of the electrostatic behavior between the porous surface and adsorbates (the −NH2 in the pore surface may enhance the electrostatic behavior with the CO2 molecules). In addition, the smaller kinetic diameter, CO2 (3.30 Å) and CH4 (3.80 Å), which makes the CO2 molecules match well with the narrow pore size of 3a (10.92 × 6.62 Å2), the resulting CO2 molecules easily diffuse into the pores. Moreover, the adsorption affinity of 3a for CO2 can be evaluated by the adsorption isosteric heat (Q st) calculated by the virial equation from the adsorption isotherms of CO2 at 273 and 298 K (Figure S12). As shown in , the adsorption enthalpy (Q st) is 23.1 kJ mol–1, which is relatively lower than those of reported MOFs, such as MIL-101 (45 kJ mol–1) and Zn-MOF-74 (30 kJ mol–1), and relatively higher than that of PCN-16 (22.5 kJ mol–1) and so on. The Q st decreases with increasing gas adsorption, and still reaches 15.8 kJ mol–1, showing the strong interactions between the framework and the CO2. The adsorption enthalpies of 3a reveal the low-energy consumption for adsorbent regeneration, implying an ideal property for separation in CO2 and CH4.

Luminescent Properties

The solid state luminescent properties of the free organic ligands (HL1 and H2L2) and 1–3 were evaluated at room temperature. As shown in , the maximum emission peaks of HL1 and H2L2 were observed at 390 nm (λex = 300 nm) and 391 nm (λex = 335 nm), which can be assigned to the intraligand π–π* or n−π* transition of HL1 and H2L2. Compared with the free organic ligands, the maximum emissions of 1–3 were observed at 483 nm (λex = 380 nm), 498 nm (λex = 425 nm), and 499 nm (λex = 410 nm), revealing the obvious 100 nm red-shift. The red-shift may be the result of the coordination interactions, and the crystal packing interactions in the solid products can enable the rigidity of the aromatic backbones and reduce the loss of energy by radiationless decay of the intraligand. And then, the structural arrangement of 1–3 may decrease the intraligand HOMO–LUMO energy gap.

Low-Pressure Selectivity, Stepwise Gas Sorption Behaviors,
and Luminescent Properties (Experimental Findings and Theoretical
